thread.title: ERA keeps the Ranger dream alive
thread.title_full: ERA keeps the Ranger dream alive

author: Peter Ker
title: ERA keeps the Ranger dream alive
text:
The uranium miner beside Kakadu National Park, Energy Resources of Australia, is still investigating ways to revive an expansion of the Ranger uranium mine despite its controlling shareholder stating its desire for the expansion to be permanently abandoned.
Rio Tinto owns 68 per cent of ERA and declared last month that it wanted no future mining at Ranger and rehabilitation of the site to proceed.
But the ERA's three person board indicated on Friday that it was not giving up hope of future mining at the controversial site.
In a statement to the ASX, ERA said it was continuing to talk with authorities and stakeholders over the potential for a lease extension at Ranger and another attempt at expanding Ranger in the future.
Advertisement "Discussions are continuing with the Northern Territory and Commonwealth Governments and the representatives of the Mirarr Traditional Owners regarding an extension to the Ranger authority," the company said.
"ERA will continue to conserve cash until it has greater certainty in relation to the authority extension. This will allow ERA to revisit the project's economics over time."
Rio has offered to cover any funding shortfall that may arise in the rehabilitation process, so long as ERA agrees to give up hope of a future expansion.
The traditional owners of the Ranger site indicated in June that they would not support an extension of the Ranger lease beyond its current expiry in 2021.
The traditional owners could not be contacted on Friday but were expected to make a statement over the weekend.
ERA has not mined at the Ranger site for more than four years but has continued to sell uranium oxide extracted from stockpiles at Ranger.
The company produced 390 tonnes of uranium oxide in the June quarter, which was 20 per cent less than in the March quarter.
ERA also updated its mineral resource estimate for the Ranger expansion project, which is now estimated to contain 43,858 tonnes of uranium oxide, up from 34,761 tonnes.
But the increased resource size was partially due to ERA lowering its uranium grade threshold, which enabled it to include ores that were previously excluded from the resource estimate for being too low grade.
ERA shares closed half a cent lower at 39Â¢.
